column4: How can I automatically run sudo mount -t cifs -o domain=egr,username=bfortino,password=[censored] ,ro //samba.egr.msu.edu/web /media/web during bootup?
arrange it into filesystem directory type options 0 0 format and put it into /etc/fstab
//samba.egr.msu.edu/web /media/web cifs domain=egr,username=bfortino,password=[censored] ,ro 0 0
How do I add rw pe... nevermind. :/
first, paste the output of "ls -dl /media/web"
also, advise you to change that password now :)
what's your username on that system?
on your home system?
anyway, if you don't want to answer that, mentally replace <u> with your username: "sudo chown <u>:<u> /media/web"
secondly, add ,umask=000 to the options in that fstab
Forget that. Just do the fstab line.
//samba.egr.msu.edu/web /media/web cifs domain=egr,username=bfortino,password=dtzo7kalai,rw,umask=000 0 0
my line should work.
did you unmount it first?
then it's mounted more than once. Run "sudo umount /media/web" repeatedly until it tells you it's not mounted. Then mount -a.
you sure that wasn't supposed to be umask=777?
positive.
I've followed your instructions, but /media/web is still read only to normal users. GRRRR.
how about "sudo chown -R 777 /media/web"?
my last suggestion is to add ,defaults to that options line.
this is what my current fstab line looks like, //samba.egr.msu.edu/web /media/web cifs defaults,uid=1000,gid=1000,domain=egr,username=bfortino,password=dtzo7kalai,rw,umask=000 0 0
